episodes.text: I've been feeling really anxious lately, especially at work. The deadlines keep piling up and I can't seem to focus. My sleep has been terrible - I wake up at 3am most nights thinking about unfinished tasks.

Work stress is still bad. I noticed the anxiety gets worse on Sunday evenings when I think about Monday. I tried the breathing exercises you suggested and they helped a little. Still waking up at 3am though.

Something interesting happened this week. I realized the anxiety isn't just about work deadlines - it's about feeling like I'm not good enough. When my manager praised my report, I felt relief instead of pride. The 3am wake-ups are down to about twice a week now.

I had a panic attack at work on Wednesday. It was triggered by an unexpected meeting invite from senior leadership. I immediately assumed I was in trouble. The breathing exercises didn't help this time. I left early and felt ashamed about it.

The leadership meeting turned out to be fine - they wanted my input on a new project. I've been reflecting on why I always assume the worst. I think it goes back to my childhood when being called to the principal's office always meant trouble. The pattern of catastrophic thinking is becoming clearer to me.

Better week overall. I caught myself catastrophizing twice and was able to stop and reframe. The 3am wake-ups are almost gone - maybe once this week. I'm starting to see that my anxiety follows a pattern: ambiguous situation -> assume worst -> physical symptoms -> avoidance.

I volunteered for the new project presentation to leadership. A month ago I would have avoided this completely. I still felt nervous but I recognized it as excitement mixed with fear, not just pure dread. My manager noticed the change and mentioned it.

The presentation went well. I had some anxiety beforehand but used the breathing techniques and they actually worked this time. I think the difference is that I wasn't in full panic mode. Sleep is much better - only woke up once at 3am this whole week, and I was able to fall back asleep.

Had a setback this week. A colleague made a critical comment about my code in a review and I spiraled. Went right back to the not good enough feeling. But here's the difference - I recognized the spiral within hours instead of days. I reached out to the colleague and it was just a technical disagreement, nothing personal.

I'm seeing real progress. The anxiety is still there but it's more manageable. I can identify the triggers now: ambiguous authority figures, perceived criticism, and Sunday evening anticipation. The catastrophic thinking pattern is weakening. I'm sleeping through the night most days. I want to keep working on the core belief about not being good enough.
Just started using the new dashboard feature. The layout is confusing - I can't find where to export reports. Had to ask support. The search function is fast though, I'll give them that.

Found the export button after the support team told me it's under the three-dot menu. That's not intuitive at all. Also, the exported CSV is missing the timestamp column which I need for my analysis. Please add timestamp to CSV exports.

The latest update added timestamps to exports - thank you! But now the date format is YYYY-DD-MM which breaks my spreadsheet formulas. Standard ISO format YYYY-MM-DD would be much better. The dashboard layout is still confusing but I'm getting used to it.

Export date format is fixed now, works perfectly with my tools. I'd really like a scheduled export feature so I don't have to manually export every week. Also noticed the dashboard loads much faster this month compared to January.

The scheduled export feature is exactly what I needed. Set it up to run every Monday morning. My workflow is so much smoother now. One more thing - it would be great if the export could go directly to our S3 bucket instead of just email. We process about 50 reports a week and downloading from email is tedious.

questions.prompt: What pattern of anxiety triggers has emerged for this client over the course of therapy, and how has their ability to manage these triggers changed?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: The client shows a pattern of catastrophic thinking triggered by ambiguous authority situations (unexpected meetings, criticism). This is rooted in childhood experiences (principal's office). Over time, they have progressively improved: from panic attacks and avoidance to recognizing the pattern, reframing thoughts, and volunteering for challenging situations. Sleep disturbance (3am wake-ups) has decreased from nightly to rare.
key_facts: progressive improvement in recognition and management

questions.prompt: What happened during the client's session on January 15th?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: On January 15th, the client reported feeling really anxious, especially at work. Deadlines were piling up and they couldn't focus. Their sleep was terrible - waking up at 3am most nights thinking about unfinished tasks.

questions.prompt: Based on the full history of sessions, what should the therapist focus on next with this client?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: The therapist should focus on the core belief of 'not being good enough' that underlies the catastrophic thinking pattern. While the client has made progress in recognizing and managing surface-level anxiety triggers, the deeper self-worth issue (feeling relief instead of pride at praise, spiraling after criticism) remains the root cause. Continued work on cognitive reframing at the belief level rather than just the thought level would be beneficial.
key_facts: focus on core belief about not being good enough
client has made progress on surface-level management

questions.prompt: How have this user's export feature requirements evolved over time?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: The user's export requirements evolved through four stages: (1) basic discoverability - couldn't find the export button, (2) data completeness - needed timestamp column in CSV, (3) format correctness - needed ISO date format YYYY-MM-DD, (4) workflow automation - wanted scheduled exports and direct S3 integration. The progression shows increasing sophistication from basic access to enterprise workflow integration.
key_facts: needed timestamp column added to CSV

questions.prompt: What specific issue did the user report about the CSV export date format?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: The user reported that the exported CSV used YYYY-DD-MM date format which broke their spreadsheet formulas. They requested the standard ISO format YYYY-MM-DD instead.

questions.prompt: Based on this user's feedback history, what should the product team prioritize next?

ground_truth.canonical_answer: The product team should prioritize adding S3 bucket integration for scheduled exports. The user processes about 50 reports a week and downloading from email is tedious. Given the user's pattern of increasingly sophisticated automation needs, direct cloud storage integration would address their current pain point and align with their trajectory toward enterprise workflow automation.
